thread.title: Bill Belichick: Tom Brady is ‘one of the toughest players in the league’ Patriots
thread.title_full: Bill Belichick: Tom Brady is ‘one of the toughest players in the league’ - Patriots

author: Chris Greenberg
title: Bill Belichick: Tom Brady is ‘one of the toughest players in the league’ Patriots
text:
The Dallas Cowboys knocked down Tom Brady. But the Dallas Cowboys did not stop Tom Brady.
After being sacked just six times in the Patriots’ first three games of the 2015 season, Brady was sacked five times in the first half by the Cowboys on Sunday. Brady persevered through the pressure and led the Patriots to a 30-6 win .
Patriots head coach Bill Belichick didn’t even have patience for questions about possible questions about Brady’s toughness after the win.
 “I don’t think it’s overlooked,” Belichick responded on Sunday when a reporter asked about Brady’s resiliency and toughness possibly being overlooked by some. “I don’t think anybody questions Tom’s toughness. Who has ever done that?”
After the reporter attempted to clarify the question, Belichick made it clear how he feels about Brady’s toughness.
“I think Tom is one of the toughest players in the league,” he said .
While Belichick may not have heard about it, former NFL linebacker Bart Scott, a longtime rival of the Patriots while playing with the Ravens and Jets, did recently question Brady’s toughness while comparing him to injured Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger.
“There’s nothing tough about Tom Brady,” Scott said during an appearance on CBS Sports Radio on Sept. 30. “The toughest thing about Tom Brady is his chin because it has the dimple in it, which is characteristic of most super heroes.”
While Belichick would likely have taken issue with Scott’s assessment of Brady’s toughness, perhaps they could have agreed on the Patriots’ quarterback resembling a super hero.
PHOTOS: Patriots vs. Cowboys
 The New England Patriots took their undefeated record into the Lone Star State in a Week 5 matchup against the Dallas Cowboys. Brandon Wade / AP Cowboys fan Juan Rodriguez has his face painted by Melinda Balderas before they hosted the Patriots on Sunday. Brandon Wade / AP Chris McDonagh throws a football outside AT&T Stadium before the game. Tim Sharp / AP Food is grilled during the tailgate. Tim Sharp / AP Delia Vasquez dances with Dallas Cowboys mascot Rowdy. Tim Sharp / AP October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month. Brandon Wade / AP Patriots wide receiver Brandon LaFell practices before the sea of pink shirts. Tim Sharp / AP Tom Brady takes the field through a swarm of fanfare. Jim Davis / The Bostone Globe Patriots owner Robert Kraft talks with Cowboys owner Jerry Jones on the field before the game. Tim Sharp / AP Cowboys quarterback Brandon Weeden warms up. Brandon Wade / AP Gronk stretch. Tim Sharp / AP Cowboys backup and former Patriots quarterback Matt Cassel (right) is also active. Mike Stone / Getty Images Back from their respective suspensions, the Cowboys’ Greg Hardy and Rolando McClain got to Brady early. Brandon Wade / AP Weeden didn’t get by unscathed either -- seen here after being sacked by Dont’a Hightower. Tim Sharp / AP Cowboys offensive leaders Dez Bryant and Tony Romo, both injured, watched the game from the sidelines. Brandon Wade/ AP, Christian Peterson / Getty Images Brady pitches the ball to running back LaGarrette Blount. Tim Sharp / AP Brady celebrates after a one-yard quarterback sneak to score the only touchdown of the first half. Brandon Wade / AP Stephen Gostkowski hits a career-long 57-yard field goal to put the Patriots up 13-3 at halftime. Tim Sharp / AP Dion Lewis dives into the end zone after eluding multiple defenders on a 10-yard touchdown reception in the second half. Tim Sharp / AP Rob Ninkovich applies pressure on Weeden, throwing from his own end zone. Christian Petersen / Getty Images Julian Edelman put the Patriots up 27-6 with a 59-yard catch-and-run for a touchdown. Mike Stone / Getty Images Yet another diving Edelman photo. Christian Petersen / Getty Images Final score: Patriots win, 30-6. Erich Schlegel / USA Today
